newsitem.title: USA: U.S. crop progress highlights - USDA.
newsitem.headline: U.S. crop progress highlights - USDA.

text.p: The U.S. Agriculture Department Monday said 75 percent of the U.S. corn crop was in good-to-excellent condition, compared with 74 percent one year ago and the five-year average of 61 percent.
In a report on conditions for the week ended July 6, USDA said 1 percent of the corn crop was very poor, 4 percent poor, 20 percent fair, 57 percent in good and 18 percent excellent.
Among the 17 major corn-producing states, 5 percent of the corn crop had silked, compared to 6 percent one year ago and a five-year average of 7 percent, USDA said.
The U.S. soybean crop was rated 1 percent very poor, 5 percent poor, 26 percent fair, 56 percent good and 12 percent excellent, USDA said.
The agency said 9 percent of the soybean crop was blooming, compared to 6 percent one year ago and a five-year average of 11 percent.
The department said 2 percent of the cotton crop was very poor, 11 percent poor, 27 percent fair, 49 percent good and 11 percent excellent.
Some 46 percent of the winter wheat crop was harvested, compared to 52 percent one year ago and a five-year average of 48 percent, USDA said.
The department said 2 percent of the winter wheat crop was in very poor condition, 7 percent poor, 26 percent fair, 52 percent good and 13 percent excellent.
In spring wheat fields, 3 percent was rated very poor, 13 percent was poor, 36 percent was fair, 41 percent was good and 7 percent was excellent, USDA said.
